title: GPT-5 bio bug bounty call
optimized_headline: "Discover the GPT-5 Bio Bug Bounty: How to Participate"
raw_excerpt: OpenAI invites researchers to its Bio Bug Bounty. Test GPT-5’s safety with a universal jailbreak prompt and win up to $25,000.
raw_body: OpenAI invites researchers to its Bio Bug Bounty. Test GPT-5’s safety with a universal jailbreak prompt and win up to $25,000.
speedrun: OpenAI has launched a Bio Bug Bounty program, encouraging researchers to test the safety of its GPT-5 model. Participants can use a universal jailbreak prompt to identify vulnerabilities and potentially earn rewards of up to $25,000. This initiative highlights OpenAI's commitment to safety and transparency in AI development. The timing is crucial as AI technologies face increasing scrutiny regarding their ethical implications and security.
why_it_matters: This program provides a direct opportunity for researchers to contribute to AI safety, potentially benefiting users by identifying flaws before they can be exploited.
It reflects a broader trend in the tech industry, where companies are increasingly engaging the community to enhance product security and trustworthiness.

lenses.eli12: OpenAI is asking researchers to help find safety issues in its new GPT-5 model through a bug bounty program. Think of it like a treasure hunt where you get rewarded for finding hidden problems. This matters because it helps make AI safer for everyone by addressing issues before they become serious.
lenses.pm: For product managers and founders, this bug bounty program highlights the importance of user safety in AI products. Engaging researchers can reduce risks and improve product reliability, potentially lowering costs associated with security breaches. It's a practical step that could enhance user trust and satisfaction.
lenses.engineer: From a technical standpoint, the Bio Bug Bounty focuses on identifying vulnerabilities in GPT-5 using a universal jailbreak prompt. This approach allows for a systematic evaluation of the model's defenses against misuse. While the program encourages broad participation, the effectiveness of results will depend on the diversity and expertise of the testers involved.
